A supremely fun tactics and merc company sim disguised as a corny 90s action movie. It's not perfect, but it's a top-tier choice in the turn-based-tactics genre. For a AA game, this has tons of polish: great environments, characters  and animations, solid combat, lots of interesting quests and sidequests. I also love that you get to make your own merc. Playing this after a recent run through XCom: Enemy Unknown makes me really appreciate the lack of RNG wackiness in JA3 (i.e. missing 75% of shots that should hit 75% of the time).

This game is a middle way betwen XCOM and Tactical RPG.

But either way is a great game with a healthy mod scene.

Fans of the series will settle in quickly, and anyone who enjoys turn-based tactics will feel right at home. Familiar mechanics like overwatch and holding defensive positions remain intact, but it is the additional layers built on top of these foundations that allow Jagged Alliance 3 to truly shine. It delivers the exact kind of one-more-turn experience many players have been waiting for. The game challenged me in all the right ways through planning, leadership, and patience. Even with its flaws, I wanted to follow the campaign from the first encounter to the final moments, and the journey felt worthwhile. In short, Jagged Alliance has made a real return.

Jagged Alliance 3 gets a lot of things right. Not every facet of it is a straight improvement over Jagged Alliance 2 - for instance merc variety and balancing could be better as well as without mods there are simply too few weapons to my taste. But on the whole it is a reasonably faithful, soulful and quite simply fun game. The good old strategy and tactical layers are there albeit this iteration feels somewhat more limiting at times with its slightly more linear structure and several scripted events that impose certain time limits.

The new setting is quite unique with there being surprisingly few games inspired by African (and maybe Carribean) culture and geography. The tone has shifted a bit more towards comedy - JA2 was mostly grounded and serious with a little bit of whack and comedic relief here and there and JA3 takes itself less seriously.

On the technical side JA3 is sufficiently competent - it runs well enough, looks pretty most of the time, has good mod support and mostly just works without there being much to mention. Soundtrack stands out though as it is exceptional with its actual orchestral symphonies and ethnic motifs.

Keep in mind though that Jagged Alliance 3 is a sequel to Jagged Alliance 2, not its phenomenal 1.13 mod. You will be sorely disappointed if indeed you are hoping that JA3 can compete with 1.13 in terms of features and variety.

With these rather minor caveats in mind I wholeheartedly recommend this game to fans of both the series and the tactical/strategy genre of games.

Pro:

A nice story and light-hearted dialogues with dry humor, plenty of chuckles, and not a trace of political correctness. The overall classic presentation of the story (including an epilogue, etc.) is a refreshing change in today’s gaming landscape.

In “Tactical View,” the gameplay pleasantly resembles Wasteland 3; the sectors you visit are small but packed with many neat little "secrets" and loot.

The turn-based combat is well-executed overall and it's genuinely fun to mow down enemies with various guns, gradually gaining a deeper understanding of the combat system and becoming more efficient. There's also a level-up system for your mercenaries, albeit a very minimalistic one.

In theory, there’s a lot to explore on the world map.

Con:

Due to an overwhelming "flood of items" pretty much from the start, there’s little incentive to tackle the many optional sectors and tasks. Even seemingly rare items will eventually pile up in your inventory, even with only a moderate interest in exploration. As a result, you’ll likely stick to just progressing the main mission — unless you really enjoy exploration for its own sake.

Poor weapon balance. Shotguns, snipers, and all kinds of explosive weapons are very powerful, consume little ammo, and are therefore incredibly fun and easy to use. Unfortunately, all other weapon types are significantly weaker across the board. This further diminishes the desire to explore, since early on you’ll likely get your hands on one of the overpowered weapon types and be "set" for the entire game, allowing you to breeze through most fights with ease. There’s little reason to use the less efficient weapons at all.

Dumb enemy AI. It quickly becomes obvious that your enemies almost always follow the same predictable patterns (except in a few special missions). Once you've figured out the typical AI behavior, it’s usually easy to take out dozens of enemies one by one without much resistance.

Lack of information. While there are tutorials, many mechanics must be figured out on your own. There's no hit chance displayed in %, no detailed tooltips for your mercs' stat bonuses, etc.

[h2]A Must-play for Tactics Lovers[/h2]
I played the game way too much in the first playthrough itself, often experimenting with different things, and there are more challenges still to complete. Although I didn’t play the original games, from what I’ve learned, this is one example of a sequel done right. There are about three dozen mercenaries of differing skills and levels you can choose from to build a team of one to 15 mercs and there are five more that can be recruited for free through mission progress. You are tasked with freeing a nation from enemy forces and recapture diamond mines to fund your mission. Apart from the main mission, which has many twists and turns, there are numerous side quests, often modeled around references from pop culture. The whole game is filled with interesting and humorous dialogues and banter to keep you entertained in and out of battle. The game also covers diverse environments and maps that bring tactical challenges (like you cannot lie down in water).

[h3]Now that the premise of the game is out of the way, and I’ve mentioned that it is an overall entertaining game, as usual, let me focus on some issues one might face in the game (mostly nitpicking, but some can be good QoL improvements):[/h3]
[list]
	[*]The game runs on a hidden timer which triggers certain events at certain points, so the first run may be a jarring experience for some going in blind as you are expected to be at a certain part of the map, but you may end up far away and underprepared. On top of that, the default settings auto-run time whenever you put someone to work (repair, train), while others are still idling/waiting (can be changed in settings).
	[*]While game is very generous about the save system, allowing you to save mid-battle, the weapon modification system encourages save-scumming as modifications cannot be detached and modification can fail even with high mechanical, resulting in lost parts and sometimes durability.
	[*]You need to repair items frequently, but repair requires a minimum of 6 hours and you can only repair a limited number of items in one go. You cannot add more than two people like in case of healing to speed up time… You cannot determine who an item is equipped to, main team or extras. These limitations do not make any sense.
	[*]Adding to that, you can only make ammunitions at towns that you control, meaning in early game when you lack resources, you may need to back track a lot just to craft ammo even when in neutral territories.
	[*]Similarly, the scouting system is also unreliable. You can scout for nearby sectors, but there is no way to specify which sector. It takes a long time if no visible sector is scouted, and you only get intel on a couple random sectors. Hacking devices often provide info for scouted sectors, if they provide intel instead of money; once again save-scumming is encouraged if you want to be efficient.
	[*]Your own mercenaries block path for each other during combat, especially if placed near doors, makes no sense when they can break windows to enter rooms and jump over obstacles.
	[*]Interactions (loot, cut wire, open lock, hack) often don’t work the first time and the game also does not auto select the best person for the job, so you have to manually select them. Viewing angle also messes with interactions.
	[*]Energy is an important system, but is a hidden mechanic which you can't track until it hits you as your mercenaries are struck with debuffs.
	[*]You cannot track experience gain either. Some more experienced mercenaries come at higher levels, but that is often a hindrance than a boon as there is no respec in the game, so you are stuck with the skills they already come with instead of starting afresh. It would be more useful if they came with free skill points to spend, instead. However, fully optimized builds are not required to enjoy the game.
	[*]Speaking of builds, picking off lone enemies or small detached groups with snipers is the easiest way of playing the game. And while you can find impressive melee build videos on YouTube, it is still risky, especially when you don’t have an optimized melee build. So, despite having different ways to play the game, stealth snipers work best in most situations.
	[*]However, stealth kills are not always guaranteed to be safe as the detection radius is not explicitly mentioned. Also, even though there is no ‘hide body’ mechanic, enemies would sometimes get alerted about long-dead buddies (pun intended).
	[*]Weather or other hazards (fog) affecting a sector is only shown during loading screen, but after that, there is no easy was to check that.
	[*]While some people have mentioned performance issues, I noticed music sometimes turning off suddenly, and while the game ran fine, if I tried to quit, it froze.
[/list]

Jagged Alliance 3 is a turn-based tactical strategy game in which you take command over a ragtag group of mercenaries. The game takes place in the fictional African country of Grand Chien in the year of 2001 (few years after the events of JA2). The president’s daughter hires you to find and rescue her father, who has been kidnapped by a paramilitary group called “the Legion” that has been advancing through the country, capturing towns and diamond mines. 

You will need to assemble a team of mercenaries, hiring from the pool of 36 colorful characters with unique traits, backstories and relationships with each other. Some are cheap rookies, some are expensive veterans. Some would love to work together and will get a bonus to morale, some have bad blood between them and will get a penalty or straight up refuse to work together. You can have up to 6 mercenaries in one squad and as many squads as you can afford. And each mercenary has a surprising amount of voiced lines. They often have something to say during quest dialogs, random interactions with NPCs and in occasional banter between two (or more) soldiers. It feels on par with AAA party-based RPGs in that regard.

If you played previous games of the series, you should feel right at home in JA3, as it tries to be as faithful as possible to the older games. On the strategic map you hire mercenaries, move your squads around and issue tasks like training, scouting, equipment repair and ammo crafting. It’s divided into tiles - each a hand crafted tactical map that you can explore in real time until combat starts, then the game switches to a turn based mode. 

The combat in JA3 is quite complex. You can target different body parts (for different effects) and the game traces line of sight for each, so while the cover does provide overall penalty to enemy’s chance to hit, it can also completely block some parts of your body, while some other parts might “stick out” (which also depends on whether your mercenary is standing, crouching or lying prone). The amount of Action Points your mercenary has depends on their stats and morale, while the cost of taking a shot depends on a weapon and a type of a shot (single, burst, full auto), so the Action Point economy is also fairly complicated. Furthermore, for every shot you take you can spend some additional APs to aim better. JA3 doesn’t show you the exact chance to hit (though there is a mod for that), so you’ll have to figure out for yourself how many extra APs you wish to spend in each situation. As someone who was spending 3+ points to aim every time, I don’t think I missed a single shot past the first quarter of the game. 

The combat starts when the enemies spot you. Up until then you explore the map in real time. You can attempt a “stealth kill” to remove an enemy without triggering combat, and even if you fail, you can limit the amount of enemies dragged into combat if you use silencers. And this is where stealth mechanics are starting to step on the toes of combat. As you get better at stealth, you’re going to see less and less actual combat, unless you deliberately want to shoot yourself in a foot and play sub-optimally.

There is quite a bit of difficulty drop down as you progress through the game (at least if you take your time and are being thorough, exploring all the areas and doing all the side-quests). The first quarter of the game, where you have challenging combat and have to count bullets and other resources, almost feels like a different game compared to the rest of it.

Still, despite some balance issues and combat getting undermined by stealth, Jagged Alliance 3 is a great game that stands out among other modern tactical games, and I enjoyed it quite a lot.

Jagged Alliance 3 is a great successor to the series and an awesome turn-based tactical game. 

It has a nice story with light-hearted dialogues and lots of humor, with tons of references to the old movies, music and culture in every aspect of the game. The writing in general is somewhat simple but surprisingly compelling and witty. While the game doesn't take itself too seriously, it manages to touch upon some serious topics like slavery or war crimes, but without being condescending or preaching to the player about any of that. Many quests (and the game itself too) have multiple endings, so that increases the replayability.

Mercenaries and the team building is a core aspect of the game and the series. The mercs' personalities are painted with just a few strokes and are usually built around some specific cliche, but they have enough uniqueness about them to feel different both in quest dialogues and gameplay mechanics. Different unique perks are way more useful in different situations - like Blood's hit & run throwing knives, or Vicki's repairable lockpick, or Livewire marking all enemies if you have scouted a sector... the list goes on. The only thing I really wished for is that they had more recorded lines for action replies or rehiring dialogues.

The gameplay itself is very good too. I loved exploring a giant map sector by sector, searching for neat little secrets and loot, trying different combat or stealth tactics, intercepting shipments, searching for treasures. The game has day/night cycle, somewhat destructible environments and a weather system that directly impacts the combat, plus the RNG in loot drops and even some quests adds even more to replayability value. Combat itself is awesome too and feels very old school. It's genuinely fun to experiment with guns and setups as you gain understanding of mechanics, efficiency and level up your mercs. The difficulty is flexible enough to even allow you to do things like solo melee ironman run while still remaining hard, challenging and fun.

Unfortunately, no game is perfect and Jagged Alliance 3 comes with its own set of the little downsides I noticed:
- In mid to end game you get flooded with items (even rare weapons) a bit too much.
- A somewhat poor weapon balance. You will quickly figure out that shotguns, snipers and RPGs are mad OP in terms of ammo efficiency and damage per shot. Everything else is weaker, with maybe the exception of the Minimi. This somewhat sours the exploration value since most likely you'll just get your hands on a couple of Dragunovs at the beginning of the game. They will easily carry you through most of the game.
- AI could have been better. Developers did a very respectable job as is, but player's pattern recognition still kicks in at some point and you start correctly predicting what the enemies will do in most fights.
- Some mechanics in combat and quests are unclear and poorly explained so you're left with either googling or figuring it out on your own. I also wish vanilla UI had a hit chance percentage displayed or proper healthbar for the enemies. Active pause would also be a welcome addition.
- General jankiness and some bugs.

Luckily, the game supports mods (both Workshop and external), so most nitpicks above are very easily remedied. 

In conclusion I can only say that I had lots and lots of fun with Jagged Alliance 3. Totally recommend it.

Do not bother training them until you control various chokepoints on the map and have already captured several diamond mines. Higher wisdom = your mercs train/learn faster. High leadership = good at training your mercs + some other bonues. Your "free" IMP merc should have both at 85.

All in all, the game takes some time getting used (10-15 hours?). Understanding of the mechanics helps a ton with not ripping your hair out due to "unfair" moments during the gameplay.

8/10 from me, despite its many, flaws (which are, again, fixed by various mods).

In summary, while it is obviously a tactical combat game, there is both a strategic layer and some RPG elements.  For strategy, you decide in what order to explore the map, your squads, and you must manage your teams' resources.  On the RPG side, there are story choices and you also should create your own customized character at the start (that one cost zero and it is a missable option under the IMP tab. You can add a different portrait with mods). 

In terms of fun and gameplay, I did very much enjoy most of it and it has plenty of tactical depth (it is not just move and attack).  I did hit a discouraging moment when I accidentally triggered an event that changes the map and also makes the game harder.  There is no warning for the player, which feels like a design flaw in my opinion.  In fact, I even wondered if I should continue playing (after over 60 hours!), but I loaded a save not long before to avoid that event and so I could continue doing quests and preparing better for the next phase of the story. 

Be advised that this game takes *much* longer to finish than you can imagine at first sight.  If you lack time, there are "short cuts" to avoid many fights and quests. 


PROS 
* Enough tactical depth : there are many options in combat, such as your stance, many choices of weapons, different types of shots, ammo, skills, etc.  The game challenges you with some tough fights where being tactical feels very rewarding. 

* The game design is flexible in the sense that the player has many ways of managing their team (you can choose to play as little as one single merc up to 18+ mercs), paths you take on the map, various tactics, etc.  For example, I found it more fun to hire level 1 mercenaries that have personalites I like (there are many, and some annoy me) and to keep them a long time, training them, as if I was playing a party in a cRPG.  But you could hire higher level mercenaries later and that is just one example of the variations in how to play. 

* AI is decent : wounded enemies will sometimes do evasive moves ; enemies who take fire can sometimes be cautious rather than just charge you, enemies can try to flank, etc.  It encourages the player to be cautious and tactical, and it pays off to be.  Nuance: some enemies just charge because they are stronger at close range.  Also, the AI is sometimes terrible when it does not see their enemy. 

* Stealth is a bit more realistic than in many games, meaning it is not easy.  The enemy can easily see you and you have a short time to act ... (you are not just invisible).  They added a pause button in the game (in the settings), so no worries. 

* The humor does not go too far and remains in good taste.  They managed to poke fun at various concepts without being distasteful nor sounding political. 


CONS 
- It is really too long.  The number of fights is really surprising.  There is one quest, for example, where I swear I had to go through 10+ battles.  Technically, it is possible to skip many areas on the map and go directly for certain bosses, making the game much shorter.  I am a completionist though and cleared everything: all quests and areas, but that took me over 175 hours!  Most players report finishing in around 60 to 80 hours. 

- The time management is sometimes annoying in my opinion (resting, healing, repairing, etc.), but is not too hard if you are cautious with time spent (money is an issue only at first, but managing the various tasks can get annoying). 

- Some (few) enemies take many bullets to drop, even on the normal difficulty, which reduces the tactical feeling.  I recommend turning on the Heavy Wounds option (off by default unless you start with hard difficulty) because that way units with Wounds at least have some penalty! 

Warning : need I say it is not an easy game.  Sometimes you will feel overpowered, but the game will throw a few punches your way.  I have played tons of games (I am old) and usually select a bit above normal difficulties.  Here, I played the first difficulty.  Though I did also turn on the Heavy Wounds option (it affects your own units, but I wanted my enemies to be more affected by hits).

Right from the start, I didn’t like the combat system in the new game. It tries to mimic XCOM, but completely changes the formula. In XCOM, you could win a fight without the enemy ever getting a shot. Here, the gameplay revolves around overwatch and stacking negative status effects. At the start, your mercs are weak and their weapons are terrible, so there’s no point in shooting for the center of the mass—the damage is just pathetic. The only real option is to aim for the limbs or try to land a headshot. And the whole combat system just feels "gamey", every encounter is like a puzzle. I'm just not a fan of that kind of gameplay. Of course, that only applies if you don’t clear out the entire location with stealth snipers. In that case, the fight might not even happen at all.

The difficulty curve is also a mess. Early on, even the starting island is tough until you figure out how the game works and find some proper guns. But once you do, it becomes way too easy—because you realize that out of all the classes, the stealth sniper and LMG support are the only one that really matters.
